question: It is true that an Operating System manages both hardware and software resources.
It is false that an Operating System only manages hardware and has no role in software management.
Process management is responsible for creating and deleting processes in an OS.
It is false that process management has no role in allocating CPU time to running programs.
A deadlock occurs when processes get stuck waiting for each other indefinitely.
It is false that process management is only responsible for handling files.
Main memory management ensures that programs get enough memory to run efficiently.
It is false that main memory (RAM) stores data permanently.
Virtual memory is used when RAM is full, allowing the system to use part of the hard disk as additional memory.
It is false that virtual memory completely replaces the need for RAM.
File management in an OS is responsible for storing, retrieving, and organizing files.
It is false that file management does not control file access permissions.
A file is a collection of data stored on a computer.
It is false that the OS does not manage file storage locations.
I/O system management handles communication between the computer and external devices.
It is false that the I/O system does not include handling device drivers.
A device driver is software that allows an OS to communicate with a hardware device.
It is false that an OS cannot detect new input/output devices like USB drives.
Secondary storage management is responsible for managing hard drives and external storage devices.
It is false that secondary storage stores data temporarily like RAM.
The OS ensures efficient file retrieval and storage in secondary storage.
It is false that the OS has no role in managing disk partitions.
Process management ensures multitasking works efficiently.
It is false that process management is not required for multitasking.
The OS keeps track of which parts of memory are free or occupied.
It is false that file management does not allow reading and writing files.
The OS assigns a drive letter to a newly plugged-in USB device.
It is false that I/O management does not include handling keyboards and mice.
Secondary storage stores data permanently.
It is false that RAM is a form of secondary storage.
File permissions determine who can read, edit, or delete a file.
It is false that secondary storage management does not handle external hard drives.
The OS is responsible for preventing process deadlocks.
It is false that an OS does not need to allocate memory to programs.
The OS manages running programs using process management.
It is false that secondary storage management deals with RAM allocation.
Virtual memory helps run large applications when RAM is full.
It is false that virtual memory is stored in RAM.
Device drivers are required for the OS to communicate with hardware devices.
It is false that file management is only used for reading files and cannot create new ones.
Process management ensures that multiple programs can run smoothly at the same time.
It is false that an OS does not control how data is stored on secondary storage devices.
The OS ensures files are stored in an organized manner for easy retrieval.
It is false that I/O system management does not manage printers.
The OS plays a role in managing CPU scheduling for processes.
It is false that file management does not include deleting files.
The OS uses memory management to prevent memory wastage.
It is false that the OS cannot track which processes are currently running.
File management ensures users can save and retrieve data efficiently.
It is false that OS components do not work together to ensure a smooth computing experience.
